Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Sustainable organic solar power from printed building-integrated panels
Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary project will explore the technological, environmental, and socioeconomic barriers to adopting sustainably printed organic photovoltaic (OPV) modules for building-integrated solar power production by considering the overall life cycle of the product. Research efforts will focus on: 1) validating a new strategy for recouping photocurrent losses in high photovoltage devices, 2) providing a cradle-to-grave assessment of printed OPV modules as building-integrated roofing shingles, 3) developing a general route to achieving state-of-the-art efficiencies from halogen-free solvents, and 4) developing a comprehensive picture of the charge generation/recombination mechanism for a novel homologous series of fullerene-free organic acceptors.

While solar power technically has the greatest potential of any sustainable resource, it is currently used to supply only about one-tenth of one percent of worldwide energy demand. The ability to implement any potentially disruptive technology for solar power generation is constrained from below by the performance, manufacturability, and competing uses/economics of available materials, and constrained from above by decision making frameworks (public/fiscal policy, individual finance) related to, among other things, the product?s cradle-to-grave life cycle. This project will explore the sustainability of solar power devices capable of being fabricated from novel organic dyes and polymers (organic photovoltaics or OPVs) that require low energy inputs and low capital investment. Because OPVs can be relatively lightweight and can be arbitrarily molded to flexible or curved substrates, they have potential for being integrated into building components such as roofing shingles, thus bringing down costs. This research will assess the technological, environmental, and socioeconomic feasibility of such applications.

This project will also engage and mentor high school students in hands-on learning activities that demonstrate the basic solar energy concepts of absorbing light and converting it to electricity, will share research results with a broad public audience, and will establish university-industry partnerships in the area of solar energy development.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary:

Solar power has the greatest potential of any renewable resource to deliver sustainable energy. Yet, adoption of photovoltaics, for example, is constrained by multiple factors such as performance, manufacturability, materials availability, and economics. Despite their low-cost promise, organic photovoltaics (OPVs), which use earth-abundant carbon-based materials to convert light to electricity, suffer from poorly understood efficiency losses that limit their widespread deployment. This project provided new insight into fundamental properties of OPV materials to 1) develop a more complete model of electricity generation and loss mechanisms that control performance in organic and hybrid photovoltaics, 2) demonstrate transformational strategies for recouping efficiency losses, and 3) provide new training opportunities and tools for carrying out cradle-to-grave assessments of printed OPV modules applicable to building-integrated system. Additionally, this project catalyzed new hands-on science outreach activities and stimulated numerous public engagement events centered on widening the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) pipeline.

 

Intellectual Merit

By combining advanced spectroscopy, synthetic chemistry, and device engineering, this project contributed new insight into important questions in the field of organic optoelectronics and more generally to the field of electron transfer kinetics. For example, “How do the nature of recombination pathways influence light-to-electricity conversion efficiency?” These findings are reported in a series of 10 peer-reviewed scientific articles. When a solar cell efficiently turns sunlight into electricity, the energy from the sun effectively pulls apart two opposite charges that are attracted to each other. Negative charge is pushed in one direction and positive charge in the other direction, producing the electricity flow that can power an appliance or charge a mobile phone.  However, if a positive charge reencounters a negative charge in the cell, the two charges can again become stuck to one another, halting the flow of electricity. This process of re-attraction and the resulting power loss is called charge recombination. The underlying photophysics of OPV materials leads to the possibility that these recombination events can produce positive and negative charge pairs in which the quantum mechanical property of electrons known as “spin” can lead to different configurations. Prior to this NSF-funded project, it was commonly assumed that certain spin configurations, called triplet states, were unavoidable energy loss pathways. One major finding of this project was the discovery that triplet energy levels need not limit photocurrent collection in OPVs [Schlenker, et al. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134 (48), 19661]. In fact, the formation and decay rates of triplet states in organic solar cells are governed by a balance between spin, thermodynamics, and charge delocalization. This balance enables high-performance organic solar cell materials to recover electricity from spin configurations that were previously regarded as efficiency-limiting dead ends. [Rao, Chow, Gelinas, Schlenker, et al., Nature 2013, 500 (7463), 43]. These significant results of this NSF award were featured in science news outlets, such as E&E News, PhysOrg, and ScienceDaily. This project also quantitatively clarified another long-standing question in the field by demonstrating that the voltage of organic solar cells is governed by a similar balance between the number density of positive/negative charge pairs and the electronic coupling between molecular components in the photoactive layer of these devices [Sulas, et al., Chem. Mater. 2015, 27 (19), 6583]. This work was so well-received and deemed so potentially impactful, that this paper was selected out of all American Chemical Society (ACS) journal articles to be featured among the ACS Editors’ Choice® list for unrestricted open access to increase its global distribution. These findings helped lay the groundwork to demonstrate new concepts that led to increased device performance in organic/inorganic hybrid solar cells by modulating the nature of excited states that control charge recombination [Li, et al. Mater. Horiz. 2015, 2 (4), 414]. The results of this NSF project help to identify promising new molecular design motifs to recoup lost efficiency in future organic and other thin-film solar cells.

 

 

Broader Impacts

This project provided cross-cutting and unique opportunities for interdisciplinary human resource development through activities like formal training for the PI in the field of life-cycle assessment (LCA), which is outside of the PI’s home discipline of chemistry, and science communication training through the Pacific Science Center, a Seattle-based science museum. The PI also partnered with University of Washington (UW) STEM education programs and others to develop tools for hands on learning and to staff more than 30 major science outreach events, with clean energy as a hook for public engagement. One example was a summer hands-on science workshop, where the PI coached 64 Seattle-area high school students in building their own solar-powered water splitting systems. This event was a partnership with UW’s Math Science Upward Bound program, a unit of the Office of Minority Affairs & Diversity, serving students typically underrepresented in STEM-related fields, particularly, high school students with the potential to become the first in their families to attend college.

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2016
Modified by: Cody W Schlenker
